{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Archer/Park | image = Archer_Park.JPG | caption = Randy Archer (left) and Johnny Park | image_size = | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 1994 | label = [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]] |spinoffs = The Parks | past_members = Randy Archer
Johnny Park }} '''Archer/Park''' was an American [[country music]] duo composed of singer-songwriters Randy Archer and Johnny Park. Signed to [[Atlantic Records]] in 1994, the duo released its sole album, ''We Got a Lot in Common'', that year. Two of the album's singles entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts: "Where There's Smoke" at No. 29 and the title track at No. 63. ==Biography== Archer/Park consisted of songwriters and vocalists Randy Archer (born February 20, 1959, in [[Swainsboro, Georgia]]) and Johnny Park (born October 30, 1957, in [[Arlington, Texas]]).{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|page=26|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}} The two had success writing songs for other country music artists, and began working together in the same publishing company. As a result, they decided to form a duo and signed with [[Atlantic Records]]' Nashville branch in 1994. They recorded their debut album ''We Got a Lot in Common'' that same year.{{cite web | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/278541488/ | title=Archer/Park: Where there's 'Smoke', there's fire | publisher=Star-Gazette | date=September 29, 1994 | accessdate=May 31, 2022 | pages=5}} The album's two singles "Where There's Smoke" and "We Got a Lot in Common" both charted on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]]. The album received a mixed review from John P. McLaughlin of the Alberta ''Province'', who thought the album was "generic" and derivative of [[Brooks & Dunn]].{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/503354357 | title=Reviews | work=The Province | date=January 26, 1995 | accessdate=May 31, 2022 | pages=B4}} An uncredited review in ''[[Gavin Report]]'' described the title track favorably, saying that the duo showed a sense of humor on it.{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Gavin-Report/90/94/Gavin-1994-11-18.pdf | title=Reviews | journal=Gavin Report | pages=36 | date=November 18, 1994}} After their only album, Archer resumed working as a songwriter, with [[Tim McGraw]] and [[John Michael Montgomery]] being among the acts who recorded his songs.{{cite web |url=http://www.countrymusicnews.ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=1055 |title=Randy Archer: Shots in the Dark |accessdate=January 6, 2008 |work=Country Music News}} He and Park also wrote songs for Montgomery and for [[Elbert West]]. In 2006, Archer independently released an album titled ''Shots in the Dark''. In 2009, Park and his son, Clint, formed the duo The Parks, which signed to [[Lyric Street Records]] subsidiary Carolwood Records.{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2954 |title=The Parks go digital route |accessdate=July 25, 2009 |date=June 5, 2009 |work=[[Country Standard Time]]}} Park also co-wrote [[Easton Corbin]]'s "[[Roll with It (Easton Corbin song)|Roll with It]]".{{cite web | url=https://www.musicvf.com/songs.php?page=artist&artist=Johnny+Park&tab=songaswriterchartstab | title=Johnny Park ••• Top Songs as Writer ••• Music VF, US & UK hits charts }} ==''We Got a Lot in Common''== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = ''We Got a Lot in Common'' | type = studio | artist = Archer/Park | cover = archerparkalbum.jpg | alt = | released = {{start date|1994|9|6}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Country | length = 32:04 | label = Atlantic | producer = [[Randy Scruggs]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} ===Track listing=== #"We Got a Lot in Common" (Randy Archer, Johnny Park, Bobby P. Barker) – 3:07 #"Where There's Smoke" (Barker, [[Mark Collie]]) – 2:54 #"You Don't Know Where This Heart's Been" (Archer, Park, Barker) – 3:59 #"I'm Not Crazy" (Archer, Park, Barker) – 2:55 #"Your Ol' Rock" (Archer, Park, Barker, Doug Nichols) – 3:33 #"The Man That I Am" ([[Walt Aldridge]], [[Darryl Worley]]) – 2:56 #"Don't Look Now" (Archer, Park, Nichols) – 2:48 #"'Til Something Better Comes Along" (Charles Quillen) – 3:29 #"Permanent Thing" (Jerry Abbott, Charles Stewart) – 3:19 #"I Still Wanna Jump Your Bones" (Archer, Park, Barker) – 3:04 ===Personnel=== *[[Eddie Bayers]] – drums *Mark Casstevens – acoustic guitar *[[Paul Franklin (musician)|Paul Franklin]] – [[pedal steel guitar]], [[slide guitar]], Pedabro *Steve Gibson – electric guitar *Tim "Felipe" Gonzalez – harmonica *Rob Hajacos – [[fiddle]] *Owen Hale – drums *[[Brent Mason]] – electric guitar *[[Dave Pomeroy]] – bass guitar *[[Don Potter (musician)|Don Potter]] – acoustic guitar *Ron "Snake" Reynolds – percussion *[[Randy Scruggs]] – acoustic and electric guitars *Milton Sledge – drums *Bobby Wood – piano, synthesizer *Bob Wray – bass guitar ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
